channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2018 The New York Times Company

item.title: U.S. and Britain Seek Yemen Cease-Fire as Relations With Saudis Cool
item.media:description: Destruction in the old city of Sana, Yemen.
item.description: Pressure from Saudi Arabia’s biggest arms suppliers intensified to halt a conflict that has created what the United Nations has called the world’s worst humanitarian crisis.
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS, ERIC SCHMITT and RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: On a Tiny Finnish Island, a Helipad, 9 Piers — and the Russian Military?
item.media:description: The headquarters on the Finnish mainland of Airiston Helmi, a company that Pavel Melnikov, a Russian businessman who owns properties in western Finland, helped to set up.
item.media:credit: Ksenia Ivanova for The New York Times
item.description: Finnish police and soldiers recently raided a mysterious island. Why? Many suspect that Russia was buying land in Finland for secret military bases.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: Divers Zero In on Black Boxes From Indonesia Plane Crash
item.media:description: Families of the victims of the Lion Air Flight 610 looking for personal items of their relatives at the Tanjung Priok port in Jakarta on Wednesday.
item.description: Locator beacon signals allowed investigators to narrow down the location of the data recorders, but recovering them could be a challenge.
item.dc:creator: HANNAH BEECH, KEITH BRADSHER and MUKTITA SUHARTONO

item.title: New Migrant Caravans Trek North, Ignoring Political Repercussions
item.media:description: A migrant caravan from Honduras crossed into Mexico and reached Tapachula this week.
item.description: Inspired by an earlier caravan’s success at crossing borders, other migrants are banding together. But this is feeding anti-immigrant sentiment in the U.S.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE and ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: #MeToo Voices From North Korea: ‘They Consider Us Toys’
item.media:description: North Korean women in Pyongyang, the capital. Many women in the North who have found work as traders are subjected to sexual coercion, Human Rights Watch said in a report Thursday.
item.description: Many North Korean women who work in the country’s fledgling market economy are preyed on by officials demanding sexual favors, Human Rights Watch says.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: ‘Cold War’ Takes New Meaning for U.S. Marines at a NATO Exercise
item.media:description: An American SH-60 helicopter moving equipment and personnel between the amphibious assault ship Iwo Jima and the shore on Friday as part of NATO’s Trident Juncture exercise off the coast of Trondheim, Norway.
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.description: A military conflict between NATO and Russia would mean fighting in the cold. American troops have spent much of the past 17 years warring in warmer climes.
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Pakistani Court Acquits Christian Woman in Capital Blasphemy Case
item.media:description: Supporters of the Islamist party Tehreek-e-Labbaik at a demonstration this month in Lahore, Pakistan, against Asia Bibi, a Christian woman who was accused of speaking against the Prophet Muhammad.
item.description: Asia Bibi had been on death row for eight years, and her case helped focus international attention on Pakistan’s harsh blasphemy law.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Oxford Roiled by Invitation to Far Right Politician
item.media:description: A scheduled visit by the leader of the right-wing Alternative for Germany party, Alice Weidel, to Oxford University has prompted significant backlash.
item.description: The Oxford Union, the famed debating society, has been taken to task for giving a platform to the leader of the anti-immigrant Alternative for Germany.
item.dc:creator: DAVID SHIMER

item.title: Dove Painted on Franco’s Tomb Reignites a Debate
item.media:description: The dictator’s tomb was covered in graffiti on Wednesday.
item.description: The vandalism comes as the Spanish government is struggling to come up with a plan for relocating Franco’s remains.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Turkish Prosecutor Says Saudis Strangled Khashoggi
item.media:description: The Saudi public prosecutor, Saud al-Mujeb, arriving at the Saudi Consulate in Istanbul on Tuesday.
item.description: After a campaign of leaks intended to keep pressure on the Saudis over the Saudi dissident’s death, Turkey appeared to be changing its strategy.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: India Unveils Statue of Unity, World’s Tallest Statue and Twice the Size of Lady Liberty
item.media:description: Construction workers made finishing touches on Oct. 18.
item.description: The bronze Statue of Unity pays tribute to Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel, a leader of the Indian independence movement who helped wrest the country from British control.
item.dc:creator: DANIEL VICTOR

item.title: Bones Are Found in Rome, Renewing Speculation in 1983 Disappearance
item.media:description: The Holy See’s Embassy to Italy. The discovery on Monday of human bones in a building nearby set off a media frenzy.
item.description: News reports suggested that bones discovered in a Vatican-owned building could be tied to one of Italy’s most enduring cold cases.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: How the Far Right Is Shaking Germany’s Political Order
item.description: Germany’s role as the defender of a liberal and tolerant Europe is in jeopardy: A far-right political party is gaining strength and Chancellor Angela Merkel says she will not seek re-election. We went to Chemnitz, where the far right feels emboldened and is protesting in the streets.

item.title: Court in Hungary Overturns Conviction of Camerawoman Seen Kicking Migrants
item.media:description: Petra Laszlo became a symbol of hostility to migrants after she was filmed kicking people near the Hungary-Serbia border in 2015.
item.description: The country’s highest court said Petra Laszlo should have faced a lesser charge. Video of her kicking two people in 2015 made her a symbol of hostility to refugees.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Midterms, Markets, Pittsburgh: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: JEAN RUTTER and MARCUS PAYADUE

item.title: Rebel Leader Returns to South Sudan to Mark Peace Deal
item.media:description: “We need peace,” said Riek Machar, center, after arriving in Juba, South Sudan, on Wednesday.
item.description: Riek Machar traveled to the capital, Juba, more than two years after fierce fighting erupted in the city and forced him to flee the country.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Studies Warn Against Minimally Invasive Surgery for Cervical Cancer
item.media:description: A scanning electron micrograph of cervical cancer cells.
item.description: Compared to open surgery for cervical cancer, the less invasive approach was more likely to result in cancer recurrence and death, new studies found.
item.dc:creator: DENISE GRADY

item.title: War in Yemen: New York Times Reports Driving the Conversation
item.media:description: An injured Yemeni fighter with the Saudi-led Arab coalition that is battling Iran-allied Houthis for control of Yemen arriving at a field hospital in Durayhimi, 13 miles south of the port city of Hudaydah.
item.description: New York Times journalists traveled to Yemen in October to provide a deeper look at the war, the latest in a series of in-depth reports.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Scientists Warn That World’s Wilderness Areas Are Disappearing
item.media:description: Sunset on the Tapajós River, deep in the Amazon rain forest.
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.description: “Wild areas provide a lot of life support systems for the planet,” said the author of a study that found 77 percent of earth’s land had been modified by humans.
item.dc:creator: LIVIA ALBECK-RIPKA

item.title: Trilobites: The Great Speckled Dinosaur Egg
item.description: Eggs of different colors evolved in dinosaurs before the appearance of birds.
item.dc:creator: JAMES GORMAN

item.title: The View From Flooded Venice
item.description: Venice experienced its highest flooding in a decade, leaving much of the city under water.

item.title: Global Health: In Congo’s Ebola Outbreak, Experimental Treatments Are Proving Effective
item.media:description: Health care workers preparing an Ebola treatment in Beni, Democratic Republic of Congo, in August.
item.description: More than half of the patients who received treatment survived, scientists reported.
item.dc:creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.
item.category: American Society of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene

item.title: A Family Recovered Most of What the Nazis Stole. But Not This.
item.media:description: For decades, the Rosenberg family has been attempting to recover this Degas work, “Portrait of Mlle. Gabrielle Diot,” a pastel portrait that was taken from Parisian art dealer Paul Rosenberg by the Nazis.
item.description: Despite decades of effort and government intervention, the family of the Paris art dealer Paul Rosenberg has been unable to reclaim a Degas portrait.
item.dc:creator: CATHERINE HICKLEY

item.title: A Store Had to Move Thousands of Books. So a Human Chain Was Formed.
item.media:description: Hundreds of volunteers formed a human chain to help move October Books to its new location in Southampton, England.
item.description: Volunteers passed more than 2,000 books down a street in Southampton, England, after a rent increase forced October Books to give up its old location.
item.dc:creator: YONETTE JOSEPH

item.title: Bomb Explodes at Russian Security Agency, Wounding 3 Workers
item.media:description: Emergency service vehicles near local headquarters of the Federal Security Service, left, in Arkhangelsk, Russia, on Wednesday.
item.media:credit: Russian Investigative Committee, via Associated Press
item.description: The device killed the person who carried it into the offices of the Federal Security Service in the northern city of Arkhangelsk.
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO

item.title: How the Far Right Is Shaking Germany’s Political Order
item.description: Germany’s role as the defender of a liberal and tolerant Europe is in jeopardy in part because of a far-right political party that is gaining strength. We went to Chemnitz, where weekly protests take place against immigration, to see why the far right feels emboldened.

item.title: Once at Guantánamo, 5 Senior Taliban Members Now Join Political Office in Qatar
item.media:description: Security forces inspecting the site of a suicide attack in Kabul, Afghanistan, on Wednesday. Even as the drive for peace talks has taken on urgency, violence has continued at an intense pace.
item.description: The insurgent group said the five leaders who were traded for Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl in 2014 have been shifting to active roles just as peace talks are being pushed.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL and TAIMOOR SHAH

item.title: Rescue Workers Search for Missing After Typhoon Strikes Philippines
item.media:description: Workers in Manila clearing debris washed ashore by Typhoon Yutu. The storm struck harder in the northern Philippines.
item.description: Nine bodies were recovered Wednesday from the site of a government building that was buried by a landslide after Typhoon Yutu struck the country’s north.
item.dc:creator: JASON GUTIERREZ

item.title: American Missionary Killed in Cameroon Amid Armed Conflict
item.media:description: Bamenda, Cameroon, where an American missionary died Tuesday.
item.description: Charles Trumann Wesco, a missionary from Indiana, was shot in the head during fighting between armed separatists and soldiers.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: As Merkel Eyes Exit, Nervous E.U. Wonders Who’ll Take the Stage
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany: “She provided the sense that someone was in control and could be counted on.”
item.description: News that Chancellor Angela Merkel, who is synonymous with the European Union, plans to step down has created anxiety over who can fill her shoes.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Pittsburgh, Midterms, Whitey Bulger: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: JEAN RUTTER and HIROKO MASUIKE

item.title: Senior Saudi Prince Returns to Kingdom as Royals Confront Khashoggi Crisis
item.media:description: Prince Ahmed bin Abdulaziz, the brother of King Salman, in 2012.
item.description: The return of King Salman’s brother, who had feared arrest if he went back to Saudi Arabia, may be a sign the royal family is seeking a unified response to the furor over the death of Jamal Khashoggi.
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and BEN HUBBARD
item.category: Ahmed bin Abdulaziz, Prince of Saudi Arabia

item.title: Nurse Faces Trial in Germany in Deaths of 100 Patients
item.media:description: Niels Hoegel, wearing a bullet-resistant vest, is led into court on Tuesday.
item.media:credit: Hauke-Christian Dittrich/DPA, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: A former nurse serving a life sentence for murder went on trial Tuesday on charges that he killed a further 100 patients at two hospitals in Germany.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Indonesia Plane Crash Leaves Experts Puzzled
item.media:description: Recovered debris and personal items from Lion Air Flight 610 at a port in Jakarta, Indonesia, on Tuesday.
item.description: Investigators want to know if there was a problem with Boeing’s new, best-selling jet, or if this was another case of lax aviation safety in Indonesia.
item.dc:creator: HANNAH BEECH

item.title: As World’s Air Gets Worse, India Struggles to Breathe
item.media:description: A farm laborer clears stubble from fields by burning it near in the village of Bishanpur Channa in the northern state of Punjab.
item.media:credit: Rebecca Conway for The New York Times
item.description: Though India’s government has taken a few steps to curb pollution, data from across the country shows hazardous air pollution continues to rise.
item.dc:creator: KAI SCHULTZ, JEFFREY GETTLEMAN, HARI KUMAR and AYESHA VENKATARAMAN

item.title: Disgust vs. Delight: Why Do Certain Foods Turn You Off?
item.media:description: Clockwise from top left: Fruit Bat Soup from Guam, Twinkies from the United States, a boiled duck egg with a partially developed fetus from the Philippines, Haggis from Scotland, baby mice from China and pork brains from the United States.
item.media:credit: Mathias Svold for The New York Times
item.description: “I want people to question what they find disgusting,” said the lead curator and chief financier of the Disgusting Food Museum, a touring pop-up exhibition in Malmo, Sweden.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINA ANDERSON

item.title: Venice Flooding Is Worst in a Decade; Severe Weather in Italy Kills at Least 11
item.media:description: The high tide in Venice was more than 61 inches, or 156 centimeters, above average sea level on Monday.
item.description: Days of strong rain and high winds have caused flooding and landslides, and the waters in Venice reached their highest level in a decade.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: The Number 7 Could Make China’s Currency a Trade-War Weapon
item.description: The renminbi has fallen to its weakest point in a decade, and Washington worries about how that may affect the dispute between the United States and China. But Beijing has reason to hold the line.
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: Chinese Military May Gain From Western University Ties, Report Warns
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China, second from right, touring the National Graphene Institute at the University of Manchester in England in 2015. A Chinese student there who studied graphene, described as a wonder material, now works at a military university in China, an Australian researcher said.
item.media:credit: Richard Stonehouse/WPA Pool, via Getty Images
item.description: A new report from Australia says the West is taking risks by collaborating with researchers tied to the Chinese military.
item.dc:creator: JAMIE TARABAY

item.title: Rico J. Puno, Soul Music Pioneer in the Philippines, Dies at 65
item.description: Known as Macho Gwapito, or Little Handsome, Mr. Puno helped create a distinctive brand of soul music in the Philippines.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES

item.title: France Dispatch: ‘They Threw Themselves Into the Sea, 14 Black Women, All Together’
item.media:description: A group of students during a guided visit at the Memorial to the Abolition of Slavery, in Nantes, France.
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.description: Nantes played a major role in the European slave trade. Its museum and memorial are a model for other French cities grappling with their histories.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Did a Small Metal Tube Bring Down an Indonesian Airliner?
item.media:description: Rescue workers collecting wreckage Tuesday from Lion Air Flight 610, which crashed into the sea northeast of Jakarta, Indonesia, on Monday.
item.description: As teams search for Lion Air Flight 610’s black boxes, experts speculate that a faulty pitot tube, used for measuring airspeed, may have contributed to the crash.
item.dc:creator: RUSSELL GOLDMAN

item.title: Austerity Is Over, Britain Says, Despite Brexit Uncertainty
item.media:description: Philip Hammond, Britain’s chancellor of the Exchequer, presented the red budget box as he left 11 Downing Street to deliver his budget announcement to Parliament in London on Monday.
item.description: The chancellor of the Exchequer promised more money for health, education and even fixing potholes. But worry remains about the country’s withdrawal from the European Union.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: How a World War II-Era Reparations Case Is Roiling Asia
item.media:description: Lee Chun-shik, center, one of the plaintiffs in the case, with supporters in Seoul on Tuesday.
item.description: More than seven decades later, South Korea’s top court ruled that Japanese companies must pay for their use of Korean slave labor during World War II.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN and RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Pittsburgh Killing Aftermath Bares Jewish Rifts in Israel and America
item.media:description: Ultra-orthodox Jews in Beit Shemesh, Israel.
item.media:credit: Corinna Kern for The New York Times
item.description: While Jews everywhere expressed shock, the slaughter also surfaced rifts tearing at Israeli society and driving a wedge between Israeli and American Jews.
item.dc:creator: DAVID M. HALBFINGER

item.title: On Instagram, 11,696 Examples of How Hate Thrives on Social Media
item.media:description: Outside the Tree of Life Synagogue in Pittsburgh, where a gunman killed 11 people on Saturday. After the shooting, anti-Semitic messages surged on Instagram.
item.description: Despite efforts against hateful and false content, those posts and videos are thriving. One Instagram search produced nearly 12,000 posts with the hashtag “#jewsdid911.”
item.dc:creator: SHEERA FRENKEL, MIKE ISAAC and KATE CONGER

item.title: Mexico’s Incoming President Plans to Cancel Giant New Airport Project
item.media:description: President-elect Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador before casting his vote last week on whether to construct a giant new airport.
item.description: The president-elect will halt construction of a $13 billion airport that is already under construction, prompting protests from the business community and investors.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: Synagogue Gunman, Midterms, Merkel: Your Monday Evening Briefing
item.media:credit: Michael Henninger for The New York Times
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: JEAN RUTTER and HIROKO MASUIKE
